title: Can light travel in space? - Quora

response.answer_text: You might consider travel a chain of cause and effect. My right foot moves forward, pulling my body forward, followed by my left foot, in a continuous chain of cause and effect. Typically one describes the propagation of light through a vacuum as a changing electric field causes a changing magnetic field causing a changing electric field…. This sounds a lot like a chain of cause and effect. The flaw with this is the equations are completely reversible. So can we really saw we have effect and then cause? Maybe it cause and then effect…. As such the description gives us no definitive answer if light travels. In fact if you could travel faster than light you would still observe light travels at the same speed, but you might disagree on the direction of travel. It turns out this same vagueness applies to all fundamental particles. There is no chain of cause and effect as an electron moves though a vacuum. It is only by interactions do we and effect that needed a cause. So we cannot consider travel a continuous chain of cause and effect. Instead we can define travel as any journey ends in a effect that requires a cause. Under this definition we cannot truly say something is travelling until we are certain the journey will lead to an effect. This fits very well with quantum mechanics which tells us we cannot be certain where a photon will hit a screen in a diffraction experiment until we measure it. But this extends this concept further. Not only can we not say where the photon will arrived, we cannot say where it travelled. In fact if it can miss the screen we cannot even say the photon did travelled. So we only know a photon, or any particle has travelled there is evidence of travel. Light does not seem to be special, but the concept of travel just got much weirder than I thought before I started to answer this question.

Its frequency ranges in trillions per second. This is how light makes it own medium to propagate. This is why light does not need any other medium. There is no other medium so compact. While traveling through space, light encounters various energy fields, objects with mass which absorb its energy. After traveling through space for a long time, light gets red shifted. We do get highly red shifted light from galaxies 13.8 billion light years away. This light did pass through space. Light travels at 300,000 km per second. It has speed. This also indicates that light always travel through space. It does take time to travel from one point to other point in space. Space exists. It is continuous through out the universe. It cut through all objects in space. It is inside and out side of atoms, planets, stars, galaxies, etc. Nothing exits without space. Light needs space to travel through.

Yes, light can definitely travel in space. This is how scientists estimate distances to far off stars and galaxies. There have been interesting apprehensions about how light actually travels in space.  When Newton's laws of motion were given acceptance, an immediate repercussion of that was the concept of "Relative speed" which denied the notion of absolute motion of any body in space. Having said that the next question to what is the computed speed of light relative to. It was then proposed that the entire space was filled with an imaginary substance called ether and light always traveled relative to the speed ether propagated in space. But later, based on experiment results it was formulated that light always traveled with a fixed speed in any frame of reference, even with reference to the another light beam travelling in the same direction. This result was a consequence of a new theory where, like speed, the notion of time was also considered to be relativistic and not absolute. Now, time is not how we see it.

In a word, Yes. But what man calls ‘light’ is just the very narrow band of the full so called “electromagnetic radiation” spectrum which our eyes are able to detect. All excitations of ‘matter’ cause fluctuations, so energetic ‘emissions’, each propagating as the surface of an expanding spherical ‘wavefront’ at local speed ‘c’ across all space until absorbed by something which does not re-emit it in the same ‘plane normal’ (so causing a ‘shadow’). Current theory doesn’t resolve what ‘medium’ the oscillations propagate in. The old ‘photon’ description is habitually maintained but not valid except as re-quantizations locally actually AT all interactions. (i.e. light couples strongly with the free electrons of the ubiquitous ‘space plasma’).

This is an excellent question because it draws into question “what is space?” Technically light travels through available distribution of time and values space while its own spatial predispositions (toward pressure or volume) are in a state of shift. Leibniz’s space consists of matter. Without matter there is no space for Leibniz, which is true. All space is a function of matter. Clarke’s space is the difference between points of matter, a void fitting a distribution in time. The flat distribution of time is the d’Alembertian solution for propagation expanding the Laplacian operator for four spatial dimensions. These are arbitrary mapping systems using whatever coordinate system you prefer. Spaces are not coordinate systems.

I think I know what may be bothering you about this formulation, light traveling through space. Light, composed of EMR (photons), does travel, but space is just an abstract concept, just an idea to enable us visualizers to visualize motion. What is the “stuff” that real things traverse? Nothing. Space is nothing, just a concept for us. Space is filled with real things, matter and EMR. Even a vacuum is filled with EMR. But space, it is just what the word implies, it’s nothing, empty, space, zero. Just an idea, and somehow, it seems you realize that, thus your question. So, no, light travels through nothing, and the word we use to refer to the nothing that light travels through is: space. Now we have the union of two abstract concepts, space and time. Thanks to Hermann Minkowski (1908) who discovered that if you treat the metric of duration (time) as just another dimension like the other three (spatial) dimensions, you can make math equations which accurately predict the motion of real objects without having to directly observe that motion. So now we have this new idea, spacetime (new, only 110 years old).
